integrations.qiskit.simulator.simulator#

Module Contents#

Classes#

QiskitSimulator

Simulator capable of computing exact wavefunction.
class integrations.qiskit.simulator.simulator.QiskitSimulator(device_name: str, noise_model: Optional[qiskit.providers.aer.noise.NoiseModel] = None, device_connectivity: Optional[orquestra.quantum.circuits.layouts.CircuitConnectivity] = None, basis_gates: Optional[List] = None, api_token: Optional[str] = None, optimization_level: int = 0, seed: Optional[int] = None, **kwargs)#

Bases: orquestra.quantum.api.backend.QuantumSimulator

Simulator capable of computing exact wavefunction.

Note that in contrast to non-simulator QuantumBackends, simulators are capable of simulating operations that are not natively supported by libraries/services they wrap. Therefore, simulation of a circuit may get broken into several smaller circuits. Each native circuit run using the wrapped library or service counts towards number_of_circuits run and number_of_jobs_run. However, if simulated circuit comprises only natively supported operation AND concrete implementation does not change counting methodology, each simulated circuit corresponds to an increase of both those numbers by one.

supports_batching = False#

get_device(self, noisy=False, **kwargs)#

Get the ibm device used for executing circuits

Parameters

The ibm device that can use the ibm execute api

run_circuit_and_measure(self, circuit: orquestra.quantum.circuits.Circuit, n_samples: int) → orquestra.quantum.measurements.Measurements#

Run a circuit and measure a certain number of bitstrings. Note: the number of bitstrings measured is derived from self.n_samples

Parameters

  • circuit â€“ the circuit to prepare the state

  • n_samples â€“ The number of samples to collect.
